reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon will certainly come off a dissapointment to most AirLand Battle players, and while it isn't terrible, there aren't many reasons I could think of to recommend this game over AirLand Battle, especially for its hefty pricetag.

To go into detail, let's look at what the game gets right. There is a huge roster expansion, with many new vehicles, factions, and maps. Sadly, most of these new units are reskins of existing ones, but this is true to life, so Eugen deserves some lee-way. The maps are massive and expansive. I am not sure if they are bigger than AirLand Battle, but it sure felt like it. Logistics is more important, as vehicles run out of fuel much quicker and the bigger maps also eat up more fuel. It is an interesting system that adds a dynamic to the game that we haven't seem previously, as going after supply vehicles will actually damage the enemy greatly.

Now let us talk about where it goes wrong. Oh, there are so, so many ways this game goes wrong. First and formost is that they screwed up the deck building system. Now, when you make a deck, there are only five open unit slots, where as previous games held all 10 open for use for any deck. The problem is that the game forces you to use specialized decks, but specialization is a bad idea. What if you happen to bring a specialized deck that is vulnerable to the enemy's deck type? Well, you're screwed. The five slots prevent you from making a well-rounded deck. I get they wanted people to have incentive for using specialized decks, but this was not the way to do it. They should provide postive reinforcement for choosing to specialize, like making the bonuses for specialized decks greater (and making their unit restrictions less harsh: many units that certain specializations exclude you from don't even fit into the opposing category, meaning it just removes units for no reason), not by removing stuff that made normal decks good.

Balance is all over the ♥♥♥♥ing place. AirLand Battle struck a nice balance, with only the jets being a little overpowered. Now that is flipped on its head. One SAM (or Redfor equivalent) can easily pummel a jet. Sure, anti-air availability has been cut, and so has their ammo, but now planes are weak as ♥♥♥♥ and they rarely even reach their traget. They are just a good way of wasting money. Infantry is also useless. Before, putting infantry in buildings was an effective way to ensure that area of the map was basically yours, unless your enemy used specific anti-infantry vehicles to counter. Infantry are now weaker. They die quicker, and their weapons are far less effective against heavy armor. They are, however, cheap. The worst thing is artillery. I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ went through Eugen's Systems combined heads when they thought of making artillery more destructive. Artillery is supposed to be a support tool used for bogging down and enemy and lowering their morale in preparation for a ground attack, but in Red Dragon they are an offensive tool that can snipe units from across the map and continuously pound just about anything (and I do mean anything) to death. Entrentched infantry? Dead meat. Top-teir armor? Be gone after 3 salvos. Even helicopters can get ruined by these things. It is such an abysmal decision and it ruins a game like this, where arguably balance is everything.

Then there are navies. actual, proper ship on ship warfare can be fun, but there really isn't much to it. Whoever has more ships wins. You can spam extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥, low-level ships, but nothing will get through their output of fire.

These changes completely ruin this game and remove any fun from it. It is replaced with frustration, as opponents cheekily snipe you from across the map (including the all-seeing AI) with artillery, amass fleets of ♥♥♥♥ teir boats and tear through everything you have, and make the airforce a complete waste of time and money.

I thought Red Dragon would be fun because of the new units and setting, but I just got a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, unbalanced version of AirLand Battle that does not do justice to its predecessor. ALB is more well-rounded and balanced, and it is altogether more fun. Don't be tricked by fanboys throwing heaps of praise on this game, and don't waste your money. By ALB or EE.

As a sidenote, there is ONE group of people I can recommend this game to. RD has the easiest and most fair AI of all the Wargame titles. That doesn't mean it is easy or fair, it just means it is actually ♥♥♥♥ing beatable. So if you are mostly a singleplayer type of guy, you should probably pick this up.

reviewText: Wargame: Red Dragon is an interesting take on the strategy genre. The game takes place through two screens: the map screen and the battle screen. The map screen takes a form similar to that of WW2 planning boards you always see in movies, and is quite novel if not effective. The battle screen is as one might expect: a bird's eye view of the battlefield(with the option to zoom in to an incredible range) but what is interesting is not the screen but the mechanics of battle. If you've ever played almost any other RTS then you'll know ammunition is not usually a feature of those games. However in Wargame: RD you must worry about logistics, you'll need to send in supply trucks to keep your tanks armed and your Helicopters filled with missles.\n\nThe only real failing point of this game is the lack of the proper tutorial. The entire game is summarisied in text screen tutorials which do little to explain the complex mechanics of war. The RTS afficandio will quickly pick up the tools of the trade but I fear that someone not familiar to the genre might not fare as well.

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon is one of the best tactical real time strategy games I have ever played. Compared to other RTS games it is a lot more tactical, requiring the use of tactics like countering enemy units, taking cover in buildings, hiding units in forests, co-ordinating artillery attacks, using air support and much more!

The game becomes sort of click spammy (which is where its more about spamming units rather than strategy, e.g. Airmech) when you raise the resource points too high. However there are some units that work well in large groups and others that work well alone, so you don't really need to click spam either way.

Time for a pro/con list!

PROS:
Features many units and nations, more than most RTS Games!
Play with AI or online
Great accuracy with unit design, unit names etc.
Plenty of maps for 1v1s or 4v4s
Naval combat. Use naval as a way to strike the land or to have sea battles!
Terrain affects gameplay. Trees can hide units, buildings can be used to hide in
Accuracy, ammunition, fuel and other interesting gameplay mechanics
Interesting debates on the main menu
DLC released for the game is free!CONS:
The units don't have much variety (gameplay-wise)
It's Peer to Peer so internet issues can be common
Can be quite boring without friends
Can get boring quite quickly
So overall, a great game that I recommend to any RTS lover!

8/10

One more thing - CANCEL THE CHRONO!

reviewText:
Right, so: I'm gonna forworn the reader that I'm not, like a lot of other reviewers might be, a long-term Wargame fan. In fact, this is my first Wargame-...erm, game, ever bought and played.

But played, I have.

I'd come into Wargame originally from RUSE: another game out of the Eugen box. As for RUSE, it served as a wonderful experience for me: I've sunk in hundreds of hours into it throughout a total of about three to four years. And especially for my version being an X-Box port purchased before I really had a gaming PC, me still playing RUSE on occasion to this day helps cement how wonderful it is.

So understandably, I came into Wargame: Red Dragon with high expectations of perhaps my favorite Strategy Games studio. I'd become legitimately hyped on the trailers, and I'd always wanted to try out European Escalation or AirLand Battle.

I'm not going to lie: this was a weird game to get into when it first game out. There were no in-game tutorials and no singleplayer, making the current lack of a dedicated tutorial mode (to my knowledge) a cubscout picknick in comparison. I had to teach myself how to manuever units through a private MP lobby, and that was a difficult task when I had no idea how complicated the controls in Wargame were.

There were thankfully at least a few good and decent guides out there, but for other Wargames of course: thankfully, since I purchased it, a number of Red Dragon guides have arrived both from Eugen and from the vast community of players.

To summarize getting into the game, it's difficult even today. It's a heavy difficult curb, but that's also what makes it wonderful: Red Dragon is AS REAL AS IT CAN GET, by all assumption. Playing Wargame is a legitimate way to learn a little more about how real warfare tactics, at least from the Cold War era, were like (to a limited extent, of course). Eugen put a lot of effort into making this game flow smoothly in terms of both difficulty placed on the computer and on the player's own abilities: while your computer is going along just fine with relatively impressive and immersive graphics, you're trying your damn best to keep up-to-speed in an MP game.

There's also a large amount of singplayer capability as well: the uniqueness that the deck system provides (perhaps my favorite piece of this whole game) not only allows for the common joke of players spending more time on deck/army building than on playing the game, but also allowing for players to have their own customized adventures and battles.

In addition, there are a decent number of singleplayer campaigns set during various points in the Cold War. These campaigns are decent in story and certainly immersive, and provide a really interesting challenge for the player. Of course, these aren't really the good meat of the game.

As for the multiplayer: it's really the main bit, though not required. I'd still recommend anyone buying Wargame to try out MP at least a few times per month to continually improve battlefield skill and preformance. It's honestly interesting to watch a deck go into combat, and to analyize how one could've preformed better and which parts of the deck went by the make or break" principle.

In addition
date: it must be added that Eugen consistently releases free DLC. FREE DLC. THAT YOU AUTOMATICALLY GET. This includes new maps
hoursPlayed: and new campaigns. How consumer-friendly is that?\n\nAs for complaints
voteText: they're predominately based around the gameplay mechanics and are mostly deck-based. For starters
helpfulPercent: I play as an American deck and understand that nations are weak in some areas based on historical weakness (E.G. North Korea having relatively poor anti-aircraft abilities in comparrison to some of its allies). However
votesHelpful: a few instances of favoritism seem to pop up with the French: a nationality which Eugen is part of
votesTotal: as a French studio. For one
votesFunny: the French are capitalized on favoring quick and mobile strikes
commentsCount: though in reality their units can preform a number of tasks *extremely* well. French Infantry AT weapons are some of the best in the game towards the 90's era
column16: French tanks are relatively powerful
column17: French aircraft are highly potent in all areas
column18: French helicopters are some of the fastest and most combat-effective
column19: and so-on. France has downsides
column20: but very few in comparison to some of its counterparts and enemies: thus
column21: it could seen that France has been given some relative favoritism by Eugen
column22: but I digress.\n\nIn addition
column23: another complaint perhaps could be leveled at the lack of a very solid training mode for beginners. I know that I myself would've loved access to a dedicated training mode when I first started
column24:
and a flip-through guide isn't going to help with learning units outside of a textbook fashion.


To summarize....
Pros:
-Decent Graphical Fidelity and Running Capability
-Excellent Customization Capacity
-Immersive

-Free DLC

reviewText:
A good addition to the series but a few flaws hold it back from being the crowning achievement it could have been.

Depending on the map played, sometimes the craters that appear from heavy shelling will appear to exist in a layer of dirt that exists a few feet below the transparent ground that used to be there before.  Normally it isn't even noticable but if you zoom in a lot on areas that get heavily bombarded you will see problems.  This was not a problem in ALB and hopefully might get patched in the next major update.

The game is the first in the series to let you set up AI players to use your own custom-made decks, which means you can create target-practice decks or simulate historical or hypothetical engagements (well... sort of, heh).

The addition of new units really changes the gameplay mechanics, as enemy AA defenses will rely far less on easily-vulnerable radar guidance systems.  Also, although you get a few more units per card than in past titles, the maps are much larger and can really punish you for losing certain units.  These arguments are all illustrated best in the AH-64D Longbow, which is the US's endgame glass cannon capable of turning a match completely around... or being a large waste of points never to return (you get 1 or 2 per deck, period).

A very fun title which is also relevant enough to get denial-of-service attacks from the North Koreans on a monthly basis.  The game also automatically logs you into the chat room where you can see them taunt our capitalist way of life.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I am not a big time RTS player. The only RTS games I have played are the earlier AoE games, 1, 2 and a little bit of Mythology; so my review of this RTS game may not be framed in ways similar to others who may have considerably more RTS gaming experience. I also have really only played the Destruction multiplayer game mode and tend to only play with friends or play solo.

Wargame: Red Dragon is a fast paced RTS set during the Cold War. Players control individual units that they deploy from a pre-selected group of units called a 'Deck' that they can build (or share with friends!) based on nations belonging to NATO or the Warsaw Pact.

W:RD takes out the boring aspect of resource collection and keeps the action fast and intense; It is not easy to learn and very hard to master. After 144 hours I still have yet to beat the first campaign. (My perfectionist habits have something to do with that, but only a little bit).

Pros:
- Obvious learning curve (only a pro if you're into that sort of thing. I am).
- Intense, fast paced action.
- A lot of units and nations to choose from. Deck building actually got me interested in other nation's military hardware/history.
- Multiplayer is great with friends; ignore the overall community in the global chat. Frankly just turn that off.
- The AI on higher difficulties punishes you for stupid strategies.

Cons:
- Lack of tutorial content. (Lots of good stuff on YouTube if you don't have any friends to help you learn).
- Maps start to feel a tad boring/same with how many there are. This game could benefit from a lot more maps.
- Without your own server you can't host games larger than 4v4. (This game supports 10v10)
- Lack of simplified mod support. There are mods, but the support for them could be more streamlined for creators and users.

Notes: I'm sure a lot of people may talk about 'balance' and such but I have yet to fully experience the full potential of this game and different potential strategies so I cannot rightly speak about balance yet.

Favorite deck style: West Germany Mechanized.

This is a definite buy for me. Full price. Even better if you can get it on sale or in a huge Steam sale Wargame pack deal and get the older games, too. See how the series has changed between releases.

reviewText:
This is quite possibly my favorite game of all-time. The game is an RTS in the same sense as the latest C&C4 (No real Base-building) Except it doesn't arbitrarily limit the number of units you can have. Maps are gigantic, battles are huge, and there are some aspects of it that everyone just loves. That being said, there are a few limitations that might drive some away. I'll address them below.

Good:
-Battles are gigantic
-Amazing variety of Units
-Free DLC
-Large Map Replayability
-Wide variety of countries available
-Land, Air, and Sea combat
-Immense experimentation possible
-Challenging Campaigns
-Multiplayer battles (TO THE MAX)

Bad:
-Sea is kind of half-baked and does not work realistically
-Otomatic was never sold to Denmark (Hehe)
-NO GOOD TUTORIAL!!!!
I know a lot of people complain about this one, but to be honest there's really nothing there! The in-game tutorial explains what each value means, but it never really explains how to play the game well. Many people just come in without any knowledge whatsoever and pick units arbitrarily. It requires some pretty intensive effort from experienced players (Like myself) to actually help these new guys and give them a hand. There are plenty of resources available for them on steam, but it's not always obvious where to find these.
-Planes are unrealistic as well
-SPAAG ground range is arbitrarily set at 1050m (Except for otomatic which is 2100, down from 2275)
-Tank Range maxxes out at 2275M (for no real reason)
-Ships don't fire KE/AP Rounds!!! (like they do IRL!)

Overall, I absolutely adore this game. The dings I gave it above are things most regular players won't care about or really notice. If you like RTS, you couldn't go wrong with purchasing this game and having a blast. Please read the tutorials after you do, and check out a guide or two! If you're still confused, ask someone like me who knows how to play the game well for advice! We're happy to train you new guys!

Wargame: Red Dragon is a fast paced RTS set during the Cold War. Players control individual units that they deploy from a pre-selected group of units called a 'Deck' that they can build (or share with friends!) based on nations belonging to NATO or the Warsaw Pact.

- Maps start to feel a tad boring/same with how many there are. This game could benefit from a lot more maps.
- Without your own server you can't host games larger than 4v4. (This game supports 10v10)
- Lack of simplified mod support. There are mods, but the support for them could be more streamlined for creators and users.

Notes: I'm sure a lot of people may talk about 'balance' and such but I have yet to fully experience the full potential of this game and different potential strategies so I cannot rightly speak about balance yet.

Favorite deck style: West Germany Mechanized.

This is a definite buy for me. Full price. Even better if you can get it on sale or in a huge Steam sale Wargame pack deal and get the older games, too. See how the series has changed between releases.

reviewText:
A truly fantastic RTS, this game really should go up on the shelf alongside Command and Conquer, World and Conflict, and all of the other classic Real Time Strategy games out there. Wargame: Red Dragon is the refreshing 2014 installment and sequel to the 2013 Wargame: Airland Battle. Red Dragon is the third installment in the series and provides new features and choices for gameplay while retaining the best features of the Wargame: ALB. This time the Cold War moves from it's Theater of War in Northern Europe to the Pacific and Eastern Asia. Fans of the previous Wargames franchise as well as players new to the series will be really delited with this latest sequel as developer Eugen Systems debuts it's 2014 installment in the Wargames series. Oh Yeah, did I mention they added Naval Combat?!

Singleplayer:
For those of you who have played Wargames before, whetehr it be Wargame: European Escalation or Wargame: Airland Battle, you will know that the plot line for the franchise is set in a ficticious alternate historical timeline set in the late 1970's and well into the 1980's. Wargame: Red Dragon features four new campaign plot lines set during the cold war in Asia; each is set in a different time with a different faction. The reason there are four different campaigns is because of the fact that each campaign goes along with a difficulty setting: command the South Korean military forces in order to repel an overwhelming North Korean invasion force on Easy Difficulty. Try reigniting the Sino-Soviet border conflict as the Chinese on Medium Difficulty. Repel an immense offensive by the PLA of China in an attempt to reclaim Hong Kong as the British on Hard Difficulty. And for the finale, lead a conquest of the Japanese mainland before the American forces can arrive in order to support their comrades in distress as the Soviet Union on Very Hard difficulty. So, with all of these different campaigns the player is given more choice in how they go about tackling a situation then in most RTS campaigns which I found to be really enjoyable since the game conforms to your playing style. I think that the developers of this game did a great job in not just the way the game plays but also in the storyline in order to make it as realistic as possible but still balanced enough to fight a fair war. Choosing the late Cold War as a time to set an RTS is really interesting because weaponry and warfare are still balanced at this point between either the PACT faction or the allied NATO forces. The context of the setting takes place before the information era so weapons systems haven't quite yet reach a point a point where a drone strike can whipe out a unit of hostil forces with the push of a button from all the other side of the globe. This games storyline and multiplayer provides two different ideologically parted empires waging violent and destructive skirmishes across the globe. While Wargame: Red Dragon's campaign is a fantastic embodiement of these features and incorporating them into it's storyline, the only thing that bugged me a bit was how in the singleplayer storyline the conflicts didn't seem to have much connection to each other and should have been drawnout longer.

Multiplayer:
While the Wargame series is infamous for it's setting during the Cold War, the embodiement of these factors is better brought out through the multiplayer experience. Set on a number of maps throughout Asia (I presume) the multiplayer element feels the same and doesn't stray too much from Wargame: ALB with the exception of new Asia based factions and units added to the game. In terms of map diversity however, the game does feel a bit different in the details. The more traditional maps of the first two Wargame installments were set in European countryside towns with some Urban presence including buildings for infantry to duke it out in, but usually it would be forests and farms. Wargame: Red Dragon's maps are different both visually and aesthetically. Since the addition of naval warfare to the series, the maps in Wargame generally revolve around coastal areas with dense jungle and plots of rice farms. The forests have now generally been replaced by jungle. One of the latest items of the maps for this game I was excited about was the introduction of denser maps which means more urban areas and denser jungles which really allowed for the tank battles to take place further away then the infantry battles. The overall experience of Wargame multiplayer feels like it's gotten a refreshing new update and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a good pop-in and pop-out RTS.

reviewText:
Ok this is going to be a long one so settle in.

I would recommend this game, very much so, but it is not for everyone. So you really must sit down and ask yourself some questions before you purchase this game.

1. Do you want a simple RTS?

2. Do you like base building?

If your answer is yes to either of these, then this game will not be for you. There is no base building and it is certainly not simple. This game is micro management heavy and it attempts realism, which can be a touch complicated for new players, its tutorials do not explain much.

3. Do you own Wargame Airland Battle?

If yes, go and play that, don't buy this until it comes on sale. If anything it is something of a downgrade from the past generation, the deck building is different and limited, the naval units are pretty lacking and there is no naval diversity.

Ok now I'll get the petty problems I have with this game out of the way, note they're personal opinion, take them as you will.

The deck building has been dumbed down, you get significantly less cards to use in any one type of unit unless you specialise your deck into a specific type such as airborne or armored. The mechanic for nations have changed and limiting yourself to an era is not as useful as before. To put that into perspective.

In AirLand Battle, limiting your deck to one nation gave you prototype units for that nation, and based on the tech level of the nation, it granted you extra points to deploy units with.  Specializing gave extra experience to certain unit types and made some cheaper (Motorized: +1 XP level for infantry, -1 activation cost for planes.) Limiting yourself to an era gave you more availability for units, as in, you could get a significant percentage more for the same price. each unit type had 9 spaces for cards, getting progressively more expensive.

In this game, limiting yourself to a nation grants you the Prototypes but also has an effect on the availability. Specializing limits you to certain types but gives you extra room for cards in specific types as well as changing the Xp and Costs. Limiting oneself to an era simply provides you with bonus activation points. Oh and you only get 5 spaces for cards in each unit type unless you specialized.

Limiting yourself to an era is almost useless on account of the fact that you can often not find enough units to use up all the cards you earned and if you can they're often so paper thin that anyone who did not limit themselves to an era will walk all over your deck with their own.

Sorry this is taking so long but there is a lot to say.

The naval units added to the game are so underwhelming and useless that it is almost not worth bothering with them, thankfully they cost 0 activation points to add to your deck, they do still cost deployment points though. Anywho the nations are placed under 2 flags. BLUFOR and REDFOR, NATO and PACT (Plus the extra countries) respectively. Each nation shares the same navy so the only diversity you have is between the BLUFOR and REDFOR ships, no matter what nation you choose. The ships available are fairly disappointing, there are frigates, gunboats and a couple of destroyers (The biggest ships in the game) oh and a few helicopters and planes that are navy specific. There are some maps with rivers on them, which river boats can make use of IF there is a naval corridor in the game.

That is a big problem for me, if you want to use your navy, you have to have a map with a naval corridor, meaning there has to be this huge expanse of open ocean, which is something the games AI ignores, I've seen it countless times in a match, the AI captures its naval corridor, then refuses to deploy navy from it, so you end up with a one sided ocean where you own it. The one thing I do use the ships for, is to repel the AI's nature for helicopter spamming. The larger ships have Radar Missiles that work rather well against helicopters. The AI will spam your ships with artillery and aircraft when it spots them though which can be annoying but also good since you can lure it into a trap. The one useful thing is that you can use the naval corridors to deploy extra ground units, these range from infantry to artillery and even a few tanks and even some supply vehicles. They'll be depolyed via landing craft, so it still requires the naval corridor to use them.

Next problem is also related to the navy. Would someone kindly kick Eugen systems in the anoose and tell them that naval craft, particularly large ships, have indirect fire cannons, not direct fire ones. The navy would be incredibly useful if the 100 and 135mm cannons they mounted could be fired like offshore artillery. Instead you have to have a shore line with no buildings and no forests in the way if you want to shoot at anything on the land. I find myself only using one actual ship for each team. The BLUFOR one has rediculously good ECM and a lot of radar based missiles for shooting down aircraft. reviewText:
Ok this is going to be a long one so settle in.

I would recommend this game, very much so, but it is not for everyone. So you really must sit down and ask yourself some questions before you purchase this game.

1. Do you want a simple RTS?

2. Do you like base building?

If your answer is yes to either of these, then this game will not be for you. There is no base building and it is certainly not simple. This game is micro management heavy and it attempts realism, which can be a touch complicated for new players, its tutorials do not explain much.

3. Do you own Wargame Airland Battle?

If yes, go and play that, don't buy this until it comes on sale. If anything it is something of a downgrade from the past generation, the deck building is different and limited, the naval units are pretty lacking and there is no naval diversity.

Ok now I'll get the petty problems I have with this game out of the way, note they're personal opinion, take them as you will.

The deck building has been dumbed down, you get significantly less cards to use in any one type of unit unless you specialise your deck into a specific type such as airborne or armored. The mechanic for nations have changed and limiting yourself to an era is not as useful as before. To put that into perspective.

In AirLand Battle, limiting your deck to one nation gave you prototype units for that nation, and based on the tech level of the nation, it granted you extra points to deploy units with.  Specializing gave extra experience to certain unit types and made some cheaper (Motorized: +1 XP level for infantry, -1 activation cost for planes.) Limiting yourself to an era gave you more availability for units, as in, you could get a significant percentage more for the same price. each unit type had 9 spaces for cards, getting progressively more expensive.

In this game, limiting yourself to a nation grants you the Prototypes but also has an effect on the availability. Specializing limits you to certain types but gives you extra room for cards in specific types as well as changing the Xp and Costs. Limiting oneself to an era simply provides you with bonus activation points. Oh and you only get 5 spaces for cards in each unit type unless you specialized.

Limiting yourself to an era is almost useless on account of the fact that you can often not find enough units to use up all the cards you earned and if you can they're often so paper thin that anyone who did not limit themselves to an era will walk all over your deck with their own.

Sorry this is taking so long but there is a lot to say.

The naval units added to the game are so underwhelming and useless that it is almost not worth bothering with them, thankfully they cost 0 activation points to add to your deck, they do still cost deployment points though. Anywho the nations are placed under 2 flags. BLUFOR and REDFOR, NATO and PACT (Plus the extra countries) respectively. Each nation shares the same navy so the only diversity you have is between the BLUFOR and REDFOR ships, no matter what nation you choose. The ships available are fairly disappointing, there are frigates, gunboats and a couple of destroyers (The biggest ships in the game) oh and a few helicopters and planes that are navy specific. There are some maps with rivers on them, which river boats can make use of IF there is a naval corridor in the game.

That is a big problem for me, if you want to use your navy, you have to have a map with a naval corridor, meaning there has to be this huge expanse of open ocean, which is something the games AI ignores, I've seen it countless times in a match, the AI captures its naval corridor, then refuses to deploy navy from it, so you end up with a one sided ocean where you own it. The one thing I do use the ships for, is to repel the AI's nature for helicopter spamming. The larger ships have Radar Missiles that work rather well against helicopters. The AI will spam your ships with artillery and aircraft when it spots them though which can be annoying but also good since you can lure it into a trap. The one useful thing is that you can use the naval corridors to deploy extra ground units, these range from infantry to artillery and even a few tanks and even some supply vehicles. They'll be depolyed via landing craft, so it still requires the naval corridor to use them.

Next problem is also related to the navy. Would someone kindly kick Eugen systems in the anoose and tell them that naval craft, particularly large ships, have indirect fire cannons, not direct fire ones. The navy would be incredibly useful if the 100 and 135mm cannons they mounted could be fired like offshore artillery. Instead you have to have a shore line with no buildings and no forests in the way if you want to shoot at anything on the land. I find myself only using one actual ship for each team. The BLUFOR one has rediculously good ECM and a lot of radar based missiles for shooting down aircraft. The REDFOR one is a small little gunboat with rocket artillery attached to the back, which is about the only offshore artillery in the game, and personally I enjoy offshore artillery.

Ok sorry to put you through all that, but if you're going to make an informed decision you may as well know the biggest points I find wrong with the game. Now for some positives.

The game tries to be realistic and for an RTS game it does it rather well, it is a fair bit more complex than simply building a fortress then churning out units to throw into the meat grinder.

The units are period accurate and well detailed, the whole game is really nice to look at actually.

The unit variation for the most part is quite nice, I know it looks like there are repeats but each one has a different weapon or an update to a current one.

The deck building is still fun, although different, often you can spend hours creating various decks to play in various strategies. before playing with them

The AI is still hyper agressive and it can seem overwhelming at first, but it is predictable so you can learn to plan around it. The Mutliplayer is a fair bit of fun as long as you have friends to play it with.

All in all I would recommend this game but I would recommend giving it serious consideration before purchasing it, if you're already a veteran of the series and you've played the others, then I would recommend letting this game go until it comes on sale. I consider it worth the purchase, but not worth the $40 they charge for it.

reviewText:
(Had to wright this review AGAIN from scratch because steam didn't post and save it the last time so bear with me if something seems off or typos.)

This is an amazing strategy game and a MUST have for RTS fans. Has a high learning curve so don't expect any handholding.
PROS:

+ No Unit Limits. (I've had upwards of over 300 units on the field at one time this includes tanks/infantry/vehicles/helicopters, and jets not counting my allies or enemies units.)

+ Thousands of Different Units. (Though some are kind of reskins each unit has their own special role on the battle field.)

+ VERY Strategic. (Should I postion my infantry in the nearby town and have them take cover in the buildings below or just march a few thousand infantry in forest cover over that mountain and risk getting napalm bombed if spotted by a recon unit.........meh I'll just fire a few hundred artillary rounds at their base camp and try to get lucky.)

+ Cinimatic AND Functional. (Not often does a game manage to create so many cinimatic moments yet be fully about a functional playing experience)

+ Polished Land Combat. (Land combat is pretty much perfect in this game more on water combat later.)

+ Resource Management. (Your Frontline Base(FOB) comes with a set supply number. Pay close attention as this will be your life blood. Your resoures are split into 3 categories Ammo, Fuel, and Spare Parts. Managing to supply units far off will prove to be rather challenging but all the more fun. You have a limited number of units that can deliever supplies with their own varying strengths and weaknesses. Supply ships can be sunk, Cargo Caravans can be stolen/blown to hell, and supply choppers can be shot down so be careful with them in high conflict areas as they will be high priority targets for the enemy.)

+ Multiplayer. (Yay for some Nay for others more on that later)

+ Lots of Factions. (From Nato, to North Korea, to Russia and many more)


CONS:

- Water Units/Combat Sucks. (Red Dragon introduced water units into the Wargame franchise and it really shows. What lies before you is a lackluster experience. Water combat is clunky, ship pathing is wonky and besides the many other obscure reasons I'd rather fight a donkey. Ok lame jokes aside the new water units mainly ships with the occasional sea helicopter or jet are sorely under utilized as most players have just given up on water units and maps altogether because of said problems. Not to mention maps that have a heavy water and land mix screw over infantry that ride in vehicles as they can not travel across water and there are no ships that can ferry them across. The only way to get infantry around on a water/land map is if they're helicopter troops. Eugene has something going here but it really needs more work put into it.)

- Multiplayer. (1. If you expect to enjoy that glorious 10x10 multiplayer action BEWARE! As the game will kick you if your internet speeds are too slow. Honestly I've never played a multi match until the end because my internet speed  is such garbage. Thankfully the game has a great single player skirmish mode with a very competent AI where most players spend their time.  If you have pretty decent speeds this shouldn't be a problem though. 2. Because of said problems and a few other's finding a multi match may be a bit hard and even if you do the game will kick players for speeds or some may just leave for reasons causing you to be put in a situation where it's almost impossible to win a match.)

- No Resupplying of FOBs. (Ok some people are gonna say that's what's so good about the game or that I'm a noob and using too much or I'm not playing strategically or I should have just built more before the start of the game. While that may all be true at times it shouldn't be used as an excuse to cover up such a glaring fault. If this game sales itself as a realistic strategy I don't know how they justify real world bases actually getting supplied but not here. Though you can increase the amount of supplies a FOB has in a txt file in the directory, an ingame feature where you order a resupply for limited amount should have been added.)

- NO NEW MAPS! (There's been a lot of reasons given why Eugene hasn't added new maps such as they had to take time from the development to fix bugs and exploits instead . But now they're working on their new game AOA which is taking up all their manpower. What has constantly been requested is a Map Editor or some sort of tools where we the community can make our own maps. The excuses for this not being a thing have been varying and confusing from Eugene not owning the engine the game is made with too maps being too complicated for tools to recreate or something along those lines. Really we have the original maps but having something new to play on would be GREAT at this point)

- No Modding Support. (Sure there are a few mods here and there but they're almost unheard of. Some people who have played the game for a long time still don't know their are mods and that mods could even be made for this game. So far there are a fair bit of skins and a few other mods like sandbox but nothing MAJOR grandbreaking like you know.......NEW ♥♥♥♥ING MAPS!!! When Eugene returns to the series they need to seriously think about making the franchise moddable)




tl;dr: The game looks good, plays good on land, has ALOT of stuff and resource management but water stuff sucks, multiplayer is jacked for most, NO NEW MAPS and no mod support.


Final Rating: 7.5/10  Updated Rating(5/4/2016): 8.5/10

reviewText:
Eugen Systems cut out a nice niche for themselves with their Wargame series of real time strategy games. True to their title, each game in this series plays like a mix between a traditional war game and an RTS. For example, good use of reconnaissance is vital for success, as unseen enemies can devastate your armored spearheads if you aren’t careful.  Logistics also play a big role and you’ll have make sure your units get the fuel and munitions to keep them fighting.  To top things off there are a bazillion real life Cold War era units from several countries available for you to play with. So, you’ll finally have a chance to see how the Swedish S-tank fairs against a Chinese type 59 tank. The games look fantastic too.

That being said, I’m going to have to give a qualified recommendation to Red Dragon.  If you like Wargame (or if the concept sounds interesting), and you would like to play multiplayer, then buy Red Dragon. The multiplayer community has basically moved there already. It’s easy to see why…. Red Dragon comes with with all the units from the previous games and adds naval units plus some extra sides.

I gave it a qualified recommendation because I don’t care for Red Dragon’s single player campaigns.  European Escalation had story driven campaigns where you did missions in a linear order. Red Dragon follows the Total War model of taking turns on a strategic map and fighting tactical battles. You’ll often find yourself skirmishing with the AI on the same map numerous times during a campaign. It gets far too repetitive for my tastes.

Also, the Navies felt shoehorned into the series. Naval battles just don’t feel right. The scale is woefully inaccurate. That being said I do appreciate the opportunities that naval support provides. Just be sure to skip the naval only maps.

Those are pretty minor issues in the grand scheme of things.  If you want to play a gorgeous “Cold War Gone Hot” themed RTS with friends then you should definitely pick this up. If you just want a fine single player game based on this concept then go for European Escalation instead.

reviewText:
Wargame Red Dragon is a flawed masterpiece. Flawed mind you, but a masterpiece all the same. An excellent iteration on the Wargame series, this game finally perfects the User Interface and the balance between the different combat arms, along with some damn impressive visuals. A definite buy, if you are willing to overlook its steep learning curve.

8/10

Pros:
- Amazing visuals
- A military techie's wet dream come true
- Balanced gameplay with no one unit becoming overpowers (cough, cough, Shogun 2 paid dlc)
- Developer's commitment to enhancing the game via FREE DLC

Cons:
- Tutorial is laughably useless (seriously a text-based tutorial? You're better off using ALB's in-game tutorial instead)
- STEEP learning curve (though the reddit server makes a lot more easer)
- Lack of in-game VOIP support (using teamspeak fixes this, though it be nice if the developer added an in-game interface)
- Navy is a bit weird at the moment...

All in all a great game. A Must Buy!

reviewText:
Lots of fun. It takes a little time and breaking the mold of normal rts games.

Normal rts strategy games. Get the most powerful unit(s) and spam to win right?
Not so much with this game. There are over 1500 different units in this game, ranging from infantry, APC's, trucks, supply trucks, tanks, mobile tank hunters, atgm's, helicopters, mobile sam rocket launchers, airplanes, boats, artillery and more. Every unit has a very specific function, whether it is dedicated anti air, or robust like infantry. There is a lot to learn about this game, but the community is helpful to new players learning, and everyone is always ready for a new challenge.
Going back to earlier, spam to win. That doesn't work in this game because you need to balance quality with quantity. You normally have to defend many zones, and if you have your best troops in the center (and hoping they dont die) you have nothing to defend against the 30 squads of rangers creeping through the forest, or many you spent your points more wisely, and you have your own militias to counter, but they have better troops. You need to balance your troops and with a little luck, you may survive the charge.

reviewText: Pretty good game.  Naval matches do need some work, they typically devolve into numbers based slugfests.  Additionally naval units lack some commands that would make them more effective.  This game uses a class system ie. armored, marine, support) with each class having unique units that aren't available to other classes.  In order to be at its best, teams need a blend of classes.  In addition to being able to play as nations, you can also play as coalitions.  For example, you can play as england, ANZAC (Australia and New Zealand), and Canada, or you can play as the Commonwealth that has units form all three.  Overall this is a pretty good game.

reviewText:
When I first played this game it confused the crap out of me...  I didn't understand it, and thought it would explain itself as I played the campaign...  Little help did that do...  I then started playing skrimish matches, trying to understand this game.  Later did I find out what the deck really was, then as I played more and more and experimented with more and more the more I began to understand this game.

Now that I know the weapon types, skill, level, and tactics to use, I know quite a bit about this game now...  now no I'm still not a stratigic Master, however the more and more I play with others and find their strategies, the more and more I begin to know.  Now I still consider myself a noob at this game, but the more I understand it, the more I find out about how to do things...

So about the game, let me tell it to you like this... It is kind of like chess, however the peices have already been set up by you and your opponent, and another thing... you don't know where they set theirs up at and they don't know where you set yours, now,  once you find the peice and thing you want to make a capture with your peice that is already in position... you have to consider if there are other peices out there they can use to take your peice you just used, or if you have peices that you think they can't see in position ready to help that peice once captured...  So take it like a mix of chess and battleship...  you don't know where they are, but when you find them how will they react to your attack, or defence

I give this game a 7/10 and recommend it to anyone who likes real time strategy on the battlefield that you can control a bunch opf units at one time.

reviewText: Wargame Red dragon puts you in command of a massive arsenal of cold war weaponry allowing you to out think your opponent and counter him before he can counter back. The thriving community and chat alone contribute so much to this game and make it even better than similar games. When I first started I sucked, and you will probably also suck to begin with. I mean I doubt you will memorize all 1400 units before playing your first multiplayer match, if you do then you are awesome. But my first few matches were fun and they still are now that i am no longer a novice. Even though I lost I still had fun, and you know a game is doing somthing right when even losing is fun. This game has tremendous replay potental in the Multiplayer though the campaign doesn't have the best AI. No two games will ever have be the same because of unit diversity. I reccomend reading Sandy Gunfoxes 200 page guide here on steam or in google docs if you are new to the seris to help familiarize you with the basics and unlearn conventional RTS strategies and adopt real world tactics which this game relies on. This game is amazing, and if you get bored of the game (which I doubt will happen anytime soon) you can sit in chat and talk about all sorts of things from the F-35 fighter jet to the Syrian crisis with the community. This game should be owned by anyone who loves military strategy and/or history. 10/10

Summary:  Great game, and one of the best strategy games on Mac.  If you've ever wanted to command the army of die-cast military figures you played with as a kid, then this is for you.

If you're a military buff of any sort, or just love strategy games, this is worth a look.  The amount of detail is incredible.  It's not for everyone.  It has a tough learning curve, and maybe it's just me, but I wish the interface was a little more detailed.  It's definitely heavy on micromanagement, but I've never felt like the game was unfair, just that I wasn't able to keep up.  The campaigns (which I've spent most of my time on) can be brutally difficult (especially the final one), and each one is a bit of a puzzle as you figure out what units to move where.  The ability to speed up or slow down campaign battles is incredibly useful, and a huge improvement over AirLand Battle.

I still feel like artillery is a little underpowered, though.

reviewText:
First, let me explain why I think that this is a good game and why I'm giving it a negative review. If you want a TLDR, scroll down to the bottom.

That being said, let me start the review by saying some positive things to it.

If you like the gameplay of RTS', then you will absolutely love this game. This is an extremely complex RTS with tons of theorycrafting, designing, building, and playing. It's a very refreshing take on the RTS genre because of how dynamic and versatile the builds of other decks in the game are. (For those of you who haven't played, 'building decks' is basically drafting units into a faction which you can then save and choose from.) You never see the same deck being used twice, and that gives it such a nice twist from other traditional RTS'. You can party up and take place in either small scale, or massive games, with a maximum size of 10v10 (i think). You can spend hours just going over one unit and coming up with all of the viable possibilites for it, which makes this game very cerebral in addition to its other qualities. The 1-1 scale may make it seem daunting at first, but over time you'll find that the interface is actually very streamline, which allows for fast pace gameplay on a massive scale. Overall, this game is probably the most unique and charming RTS I have ever played.

However, this is not without its merits.

reviewText: Wargame: Red Dragon is hands down one of the best RTS games created in the past 10 years.  If you have a decent graphics card you will notice images that will blow your mind.  Zoom out to see the entire battlefield or zoom in to see the dense foilage and textures on groundhog level.  The variety of units is undeniably spectacular and the gameplay is fantastic. reviewText:
When I first played this game it confused the crap out of me...  I didn't understand it, and thought it would explain itself as I played the campaign...  Little help did that do...  I then started playing skrimish matches, trying to understand this game.  Later did I find out what the deck really was, then as I played more and more and experimented with more and more the more I began to understand this game.

Now that I know the weapon types, skill, level, and tactics to use, I know quite a bit about this game now...  now no I'm still not a stratigic Master, however the more and more I play with others and find their strategies, the more and more I begin to know.  Now I still consider myself a noob at this game, but the more I understand it, the more I find out about how to do things...

So about the game, let me tell it to you like this... It is kind of like chess, however the peices have already been set up by you and your opponent, and another thing... you don't know where they set theirs up at and they don't know where you set yours, now,  once you find the peice and thing you want to make a capture with your peice that is already in position... you have to consider if there are other peices out there they can use to take your peice you just used, or if you have peices that you think they can't see in position ready to help that peice once captured...  So take it like a mix of chess and battleship...  you don't know where they are, but when you find them how will they react to your attack, or defence

I give this game a 7/10 and recommend it to anyone who likes real time strategy on the battlefield that you can control a bunch opf units at one time.

reviewText:
Summary:  Great game, and one of the best strategy games on Mac.  If you've ever wanted to command the army of die-cast military figures you played with as a kid, then this is for you.

If you're a military buff of any sort, or just love strategy games, this is worth a look.  The amount of detail is incredible.  It's not for everyone.  It has a tough learning curve, and maybe it's just me, but I wish the interface was a little more detailed.  It's definitely heavy on micromanagement, but I've never felt like the game was unfair, just that I wasn't able to keep up.  The campaigns (which I've spent most of my time on) can be brutally difficult (especially the final one), and each one is a bit of a puzzle as you figure out what units to move where.  The ability to speed up or slow down campaign battles is incredibly useful, and a huge improvement over AirLand Battle.

I still feel like artillery is a little underpowered, though.

reviewText: Wargame Red dragon puts you in command of a massive arsenal of cold war weaponry allowing you to out think your opponent and counter him before he can counter back. The thriving community and chat alone contribute so much to this game and make it even better than similar games. When I first started I sucked, and you will probably also suck to begin with. I mean I doubt you will memorize all 1400 units before playing your first multiplayer match, if you do then you are awesome. But my first few matches were fun and they still are now that i am no longer a novice. Even though I lost I still had fun, and you know a game is doing somthing right when even losing is fun. This game has tremendous replay potental in the Multiplayer though the campaign doesn't have the best AI. No two games will ever have be the same because of unit diversity. I reccomend reading Sandy Gunfoxes 200 page guide here on steam or in google docs if you are new to the seris to help familiarize you with the basics and unlearn conventional RTS strategies and adopt real world tactics which this game relies on. This game is amazing, and if you get bored of the game (which I doubt will happen anytime soon) you can sit in chat and talk about all sorts of things from the F-35 fighter jet to the Syrian crisis with the community. This game should be owned by anyone who loves military strategy and/or history. 10/10

reviewText:
First, let me explain why I think that this is a good game and why I'm giving it a negative review. If you want a TLDR, scroll down to the bottom.

That being said, let me start the review by saying some positive things to it.

If you like the gameplay of RTS', then you will absolutely love this game. This is an extremely complex RTS with tons of theorycrafting, designing, building, and playing. It's a very refreshing take on the RTS genre because of how dynamic and versatile the builds of other decks in the game are. (For those of you who haven't played, 'building decks' is basically drafting units into a faction which you can then save and choose from.) You never see the same deck being used twice, and that gives it such a nice twist from other traditional RTS'. You can party up and take place in either small scale, or massive games, with a maximum size of 10v10 (i think). You can spend hours just going over one unit and coming up with all of the viable possibilites for it, which makes this game very cerebral in addition to its other qualities. The 1-1 scale may make it seem daunting at first, but over time you'll find that the interface is actually very streamline, which allows for fast pace gameplay on a massive scale. Overall, this game is probably the most unique and charming RTS I have ever played.

However, this is not without its merits.

reviewText:
Wargame Red Dragon is a flawed masterpiece. Flawed mind you, but a masterpiece all the same. An excellent iteration on the Wargame series, this game finally perfects the User Interface and the balance between the different combat arms, along with some damn impressive visuals. A definite buy, if you are willing to overlook its steep learning curve.

8/10

Pros:
- Amazing visuals
- A military techie's wet dream come true
- Balanced gameplay with no one unit becoming overpowers (cough, cough, Shogun 2 paid dlc)
- Developer's commitment to enhancing the game via FREE DLC

Cons:
- Tutorial is laughably useless (seriously a text-based tutorial? You're better off using ALB's in-game tutorial instead)
- STEEP learning curve (though the reddit server makes a lot more easer)
- Lack of in-game VOIP support (using teamspeak fixes this, though it be nice if the developer added an in-game interface)
- Navy is a bit weird at the moment...

All in all a great game. A Must Buy!

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon is a tactical war game set in the 1970s to as late as 1985, it can be both enjoyed in
Singleplayer and Multiplayer.

In Singleplayer, there are 5 campaigns based off real life events back then which the players can immerse in.

-Busan Pocket [Player - South Korean]
-Bear vs. Dragon [Player - China]
-Pearl of the Orient [Player - UK]
-Climb Mount Narodnaia
-Second Korean War [Player - BLUFOR Forces]

Each of those campaigns host a different style and strategy of gameplay which the player must adapt to and stand on the winning platform.

The developers weren't lying when they said there were over a 1,000+ units in the game,they can all be found in the 'Deck Create' option in the Main Menu.

In Multiplayer, the player can also select from a variety of gameplay modes to play from,

- Destruction
- Conquest
- Siege
- Vox Populi

Each of these gamemodes host a different kind of objective, for example, in Destruction mode the player has to destroy a certain amount of units which depletes their Objective Points" for each kill

reviewText:
The games that offer real time strategies with contemporary military units are only a few and they are generally unexceptional so you can imagine my excitement for the Wargame series. Red Dragon's timeframe expands from 1975 to 1991 and has over 1600 air/land/naval units from 17 countries. The units have been modeled with realism in mind and they even have fuel and ammo counters that you need to manage during a fight.

Campaign mode might get a bit repetitive because sometimes you play the same map with the same units repeatedly. You can also manage troop compositions and deployment at a strategic level before fights but it's pretty light. Besides the five campaigns you also have multiplayer and skirmish mode. Even though the idea and its implementation are good, the game failed to really engage me.

reviewText:
Eugen Systems cut out a nice niche for themselves with their Wargame series of real time strategy games. True to their title, each game in this series plays like a mix between a traditional war game and an RTS. For example, good use of reconnaissance is vital for success, as unseen enemies can devastate your armored spearheads if you aren’t careful.  Logistics also play a big role and you’ll have make sure your units get the fuel and munitions to keep them fighting.  To top things off there are a bazillion real life Cold War era units from several countries available for you to play with. So, you’ll finally have a chance to see how the Swedish S-tank fairs against a Chinese type 59 tank. The games look fantastic too.

That being said, I’m going to have to give a qualified recommendation to Red Dragon.  If you like Wargame (or if the concept sounds interesting), and you would like to play multiplayer, then buy Red Dragon. The multiplayer community has basically moved there already. It’s easy to see why…. Red Dragon comes with with all the units from the previous games and adds naval units plus some extra sides.

I gave it a qualified recommendation because I don’t care for Red Dragon’s single player campaigns.  European Escalation had story driven campaigns where you did missions in a linear order. Red Dragon follows the Total War model of taking turns on a strategic map and fighting tactical battles. You’ll often find yourself skirmishing with the AI on the same map numerous times during a campaign. It gets far too repetitive for my tastes.

Also, the Navies felt shoehorned into the series. Naval battles just don’t feel right. The scale is woefully inaccurate. That being said I do appreciate the opportunities that naval support provides. Just be sure to skip the naval only maps.

Those are pretty minor issues in the grand scheme of things.  If you want to play a gorgeous “Cold War Gone Hot” themed RTS with friends then you should definitely pick this up. If you just want a fine single player game based on this concept then go for European Escalation instead.

reviewText: This is a great game. Lots of great combine arms tactical nonsense, great gameplay, deep mechanics, lots of units, great graphics. Be warned: this game has a steep learning curve, and it's much more based in real world tactics than your standard RTS. The addition of naval units is pretty fun, as now everything from river gunboats to destroyers is added to the fray, along with your standard assortment of tanks, trucks, planes, helicopters, and infantry. The number of units is pretty astounding, though I'd say about 40-50% of them are just recolors with new camo and maybe a different gun on top. This is especially bad on the Communist/REDFOR side, though the USSR did basically just export its designs to all of its vassal states, so this can be somewhat forgiven for the sake of historical accuracy. It's too bad that the multiplayer community is extremely small and the people in it are awful. Wanna play a game online? Be prepared to have half your team quit as soon as you start losing. There's really no penalty for it; hell, once enough people leave even I'll surrender. It's really not fun, unless you get to steamroll the other team, I guess. The multiplayer problems with this game could probably be fixed through just more exposure, or at least a fix to the matchmaking system so that you can join games in progress if someone quits out or something. Solo skirmishes are okay, and the AI is challenging enough even on medium difficulty (or maybe I'm just bad), though I've also heard it cheats, which isn't very helpful if you're just trying out a new set up for your army. If you want a highly-realistic RTS or are just tired of the standard RTS formula of games like Starcraft and Command and Conquer, or if you're a fan of modern military equipment, I'd recommend this, though I would wait for it to go on sale just in case you end up not liking it.

reviewText: This is not a game for me.  I can't beat an equally-supplied A.I. on the same map.  Maybe I expected my minimal RTS skills to translate better to Red Dragon, but it's plainly obvious they don't.\n\nWargame: Red Dragon is worth trying out.  If you're a strategy buff and love the Cold War era and the years just after them, you'll get a kick of nostalgia out of this game. Game runs smoothly, player base is active, sounds are satisfactory, music a little repetitive, and pathing is fair enough.  You will remain a noob for many scores of hours if you're totally new to the Wargame franchise.  I can't say whether that should dishearten or encourage you.  It's a steep learning curve, but one worth testing regardless.

reviewText: Probably one of the most interesting games I've ever played. Just the units alone make this game garner my attention. There's 1200+! However, this game certainly isn't perfect. The naval battles basically consist of spamming as many large boats as you can, which really kind of takes away from the constraint of the land and air battles. The learning curve is pretty steep, which isn't helped by the pretty awful community. There is also a lot of rage-quitting in games, with little to no punisment for it. I love this game very much, and if either updates or a sequel could handle these problems, I would be very pleased.

reviewText:
The games that offer real time strategies with contemporary military units are only a few and they are generally unexceptional so you can imagine my excitement for the Wargame series. Red Dragon's timeframe expands from 1975 to 1991 and has over 1600 air/land/naval units from 17 countries. The units have been modeled with realism in mind and they even have fuel and ammo counters that you need to manage during a fight.

Campaign mode might get a bit repetitive because sometimes you play the same map with the same units repeatedly. You can also manage troop compositions and deployment at a strategic level before fights but it's pretty light. Besides the five campaigns you also have multiplayer and skirmish mode. Even though the idea and its implementation are good, the game failed to really engage me.

reviewText:
As the third entry to the series, Wargame Red Dragon brings better graphics and a wider selection of units and retains the characteristics that distinguish itself from any other strategy games. I especially like the new coalition system, in which countries that used to be almost irrelevant can come together and form an alliance. For example, the Eastern Bloc consists of East Germany, Poland, and Czechoslovakia, and each one of them hardly stands on its own, yet when put into a coalition they can be every bit as powerful as the USSR or USA. This makes a huge difference in gameplay, as now basically the entire armory can be seen in action, a very much welcome departure from Airland Battle.

Naval Battle is indeed lackluster as many reviewers have pointed out. It just doesn't have the strategic and tactical element of the rest of the game. Take a look at the game room lobby and you will see that hardly any player plays naval.

As with all strategy games, there are OP units and OP fractions, yet it really still boils down to what a fraction is good at doing and what the battlefield is like. Maximize their advantages and avoid fighting in areas where they are weaker, pay close attention to the maps and you've set yourself up for an exciting military themed RTS.

reviewText: One of the greatest modern RTS games of all time, far better than your average RTS. Features realistic combat between various units from Aircraft and Navies to Infantry and APCs. A small tactical mistake such as losing a strategic road intersection can cost you a battle. The game has a difficult learning curb but still is fun to play. Features every major Warsaw Pact and NATO nation such as ANZAC, UK, USA, USSR, West Germany, Japan, Both Koreas, China and several more nations. Each nation has at least 100-250 different units ranging between every kind of human technological innovation in the Cold War such as Jet Fighters, Anti-Aircraft, Modern Tanks, Rocket Artillery, and much more. The only thing this game needs is major Middle East nations that played a large role in the Cold War such as Iran, Iraq, Israel, Turkey, Syria, and Egypt. Otherwise, this game has over 2000 different units combined, intensely realistic combat, requires the player to make complicated tactical and strategic choices in both campaign, singleplayer, and multiplayer. One of the greatest RTS games of all time, if not the best.\n10/10

reviewText:
Wargame is a very cool game. It makes me come back to play it even if I lose most of the time.

Pro:

+ The game is ecstatically pleasing and very detailed.

In the game you can see the entire theatre of war from above and get a perfect view of the overall progression of the battle. Or you zoom in to the grunts seeing them assaulting, devastating and dying with flamethrowers, cluster bombs, mortars etc.
It looks just like in the trailer.

+AVAILABLE NUMBER OF UNITS
I guess they have about 1500 units in this game. Each one beautifully detailed with their own country typical weapons and decals. This is concerning the land armies. The naval units are not typical to every nation. There are Russian and Chinese and American typical units. This might also be due to the fact that small nations don't have the money to develop their own warships. Anyway, 1500 units is good to me.

I have to admit that there are also a lot of units that are just copies from other nations with another decal. An example for this is the leopard tank. It's a solid unit and that's why you can find it in nearly every NATO nation’s army. But even this tank has sometimes different stats depending on the nation.

+ Air to Air and Air to Ground and Air to Ship combat is the best simulated one I know in a strategy game. It's very nice and a plus to the game since air land battle.

+ONLINE BATTLES
Online battles are the bread and the butter of the game. So you will end up playing against other players most of the time. It is definitely a solid gameplay. I have to say it is hard for beginners so you better invest time to get to know your units. Which is kind of a draw back if you just wanna jump on the online game and defeat others like nothing? This is not what is going to happen. You will lose a lot of times before you win. This is because the game has a lot depth due to its huge number of available units. My mind set on playing online changed from I want to win the game" to "I want to give the enemy a run for their money".

+ UNIT SELECTION
The selection of the units is a really based on a really good system. You have lets say 55 points to put units into your unit card deck. A unit card deck defines the amount and kind of units you're leading into battle. You can increase these points to get more cards. So you can deploy more units or you invest points to get better units but less of them. You can also specialise your deck to lets say airborne. This means you have all good fighters
date:
choppers plus Arial prototype units available but you are badly equipped with ground units. This system enables role play for you and your friends and is fun on the battlefield. It also forces army variation.


BUGS:
- When you zoom in to a place on the map where a battle was commenced
recommended:
there is a graphic bug at times. The craters of the bombs appear above the ground and not in the ground.

Single Player:
- The single player is a complete different experience to the online game. With different I mean it is weaker. You have a strategy map with a lot of territories (maps) to fight on
hoursPlayed: which is good and a nice Idea because this way a campaign is fought on maps according to your decisions. This is a nice idea
voteText:
BUT there are always some strategic more valuable territories to play on then others. This results in playing over and over again on the same map. The Idea is nice but it's not well thought through.

- On top of this is the AI. It's not clever and in my opinion it didn't get better over the series. After 3 games you know what it is after and you can adjust yourself to it. The only challenge is the number of troops that are thrown at you.

- Presentation of the single player got weaker with the series progression. Meaning it was the best in Wargame European Escalation and it's the weakest at Red Dragon in my opinion. Air Land Battle isn't a far cry from Red Dragon so you decide which one is worse. :)

What exactly is weaker on the presentation?:
In European escalation you have an introducing video after each mission played. It's not much but it's better than a screenshot show or some artwork colleagues who tell you what to do. This is what you can expect in Wargame red Dragon
helpfulPercent: cartoon colleagues with speech bubbles.\n\nIn total I would say the single player is a tutorial to get you ready for the real deal
votesHelpful:
the online matches.

- The Ship battles are boring. Let's sum it up to "The player with the biggest host of naval units wins." That’s it.

BAD THINGS IN ONLINE PLAY:

ARTY SPAM:
A lot of people use artillery spam. This is pointless in my view because everybody can do this and it only drains resources of your team. It doesn't kill a lot of enemies; it stuns them at best and kills some infantry and light vehicles. But in the end it's just over used.

PEOPLE WITH NO BALLS:
If you join a game 10 vs. 10 Players you wait at first ages until the lobby is full and the game can begin. As soon as you are on the battlefield and start playing you can be sure somebody left the lobby already. Or and this is when it comes to the low number of balls. People leave the game when the see that there team isn't doing so well. This in turn makes the game short since if people leave the remaining people have to manage additional units left from the gone player. Micro mgmt. becomes a pain and you know you can't win since the enemy team has more players to manage their troops.

GAME ENCOURAGES PEOPLE TO LEAVE ONLINE MATCHES
The best thing is that the game encourages players to leave a game. Since there is a game mod that counts the number and the value of the units you lost and destroyed. If you are the last player on the map because you're a man that fights to the last man you get punished on the statistics. Because you are the one who lost the most units. It's just natural that the last player left loses the most units. So statistically wise the one player that was the best one because he didn't leave is the worst one.

So this is it about my review. I hope it helped you to get an Idea about that game and if you will give it a try or not. And my personal thump up to you if you did read the entire thing."

reviewText:
Re-review below main review now that I have clocked some more time.  See botom if interested for latest updates.

=============================================================================
Wargame Red Dragon is the game I have been looking for since giving up on my 200+ hours of Company of Heroes 2 and 300+ of Company of Heroes 1 (prior to the stupid Steam edition).  This game is about tactics and understanding what is happening on the battlefield while changing your thought process on the fly.  You can't just spam out 15,000 infantry and win the game.  Tanks, anti-air/infantry, and jets will eat you alive.  Spam tanks and end up in the same situation.  The game encourages a combined arms.  Now there is some spam, as the bloc countries rely more on quantity than quality versus the allied west/NATO nations.

There are around 1700 units in the game and some of them are very similar to each other but have their unique niche that they fill.  I'm only 10 hours in and know nothing of what I am supposed to be doing other than relying mroe on quantity since I play primarily Russia with a side of North Korea.  From WW2 tanks to about 1991, there are plenty of vehicles, tanks, infantry, air, and navy.  From the VDV, Spetsnaz to the T80, it's all here on the bloc side of things.  The Japanese, Canadian, US, and myriad of other allied/NATO nations are also playable.

From a gameplay perspective you build a deck of units that you will choose prior ot launching the game. These units are all you get, once they are gone that is it.  No base building just pure calling in troops from off the map based on whatever entrance they get.  Sometimes when you cap points you can call in units from a nearby edge of the map.  Units have tons of stats and rank up as they survive and do well.  Don't ask me what the ideal setup for stats are because their probably isn't one or if there is, I am entirely too new to understand or know yet.

Sound, graphics, and gameplay are all top notch.  If you liked Ruse you will like this.  If you want to play with people, the commnity might be a bit rough.  I bought this to play with friends agains the AI as that is what we do to have a good time.  To each their own!

There are a myriad of maps to play and tons of AI levels to go up against.  The AI does tend to cheat" in that it knows what the yare up against but with the proper planning it is easy to deal with and just makes the game more interesting.  It isn't Company of Heroes 2 cheating where they can call in smoke abilities every 15 seconds for free.  Tactics win the game every time.  When you loose to a 2v1 AI you know you are terible!

I'd like to recommend this game to anyone that is looking into getting an RTS that is more modern day and requires thought and planning and not spamming one unit like other RTS games out there.  This one is good.  Fuel and ammo play an integral role and without resupply
date:
your tanks will either stop dead or just not be able to do anything.  The realism is kept at a high level without compromising gameplay.  Is the game worth 40 dollars?  I think so but I would still prefer to get it on sale and this Christmas as well as this weekend it is on sale!  Do yourself a favor and add a game to your library you can get some major hours out of!
=============================================================================

reviewText: Probably one of the most interesting games I've ever played. Just the units alone make this game garner my attention. There's 1200+! However, this game certainly isn't perfect. The learning curve is pretty steep, which isn't helped by the pretty awful community. There is also a lot of rage-quitting in games, with little to no punisment for it. I love this game very much, and if either updates or a sequel could handle these problems, I would be very pleased.

reviewText:
As the third entry to the series, Wargame Red Dragon brings better graphics and a wider selection of units and retains the characteristics that distinguish itself from any other strategy games. I especially like the new coalition system, in which countries that used to be almost irrelevant can come together and form an alliance. For example, the Eastern Bloc consists of East Germany, Poland, and Czechoslovakia, and each one of them hardly stands on its own, yet when put into a coalition they can be every bit as powerful as the USSR or USA. This makes a huge difference in gameplay, as now basically the entire armory can be seen in action, a very much welcome departure from Airland Battle.

Naval Battle is indeed lackluster as many reviewers have pointed out. It just doesn't have the strategic and tactical element of the rest of the game. Take a look at the game room lobby and you will see that hardly any player plays naval.

As with all strategy games, there are OP units and OP fractions, yet it really still boils down to what a fraction is good at doing and what the battlefield is like. Maximize their advantages and avoid fighting in areas where they are weaker, pay close attention to the maps and you've set yourself up for an exciting military themed RTS.
