reviewText:
I have to admit, Wargame is something that requires patience, a high toleration of frustration and even more practice to master, but once you got to a point where you understand what to do and what not, it is pretty amazing.
It requires so much micromanagement to successfully overwhelm your enemy (assuming he's human, that is) that you won't even have time to grab a sip of coffee. It really teaches you to actually read the description of a unit and use common sense. Spamming 20 Tanks will cause your enemy to either ambush them with AT Infantry or call in an airstrike - and you can kiss these tanks goodbye.
In StarCraft or CnC, it wouldn't matter - but here? If your Leopard is gone, it's gone. The crew is dead, the vehicle destroyed, and they won't come back.


Sometimes, you feel so desperate but turn it around, sometimes you are so full of yourself that a single mistake will cause the deaths of all of your soldiers.

If you want complex action and a lot of stuff to learn, Wargame is for you.
If you want quick skirmishes with brainless rushes, play CnC or StarCraft (not saying either of the two is bad!).

reviewText:
Very high learning curve, a lot to manage and figure out... but totally worth it. It's like World in Conflict on crack. Many of the same concepts as World in Conflict also exist here, but significantly more fleshed out, technical, and realistic. The generic unit archetypes of WiC are replaced by meticulously-modelled real-world military hardware from the latter half of the 20th century, but have fairly easy to understand stats and weapons. There is also a huge wealth of nations and their respective hardware. While obviously the majority of the hardware is Soviet or American, the other major nations of the 20th century are all well-represented with a mix of their own weapons and imports from the superpowers.

Once you start to learn the intricacies of the game, it becomes a lot of fun, further amplified by the deck-building system which lets you create your own custom battle force. You can specialize in air power, tanks, infantry, and all other manner of battalion-level formations. Similarly, you can play generic NATO or Warsaw, or specific nations with access to those nations' newest top-of-the-line hardware.

Very intricate, very fun.

reviewText:
This is, as far as I'm aware, a pretty unique type of real time game. By this I mean they did an amazing job on things like, the volume of control you have over the camera for the best views of everything, the insane scale on all the maps, the insane amount and variety of different units that you can make and have on the field at once with a group of other people, the realistic and very realistic physics of bullets and explosions, and one of my all time favorite things of any and all real time strategy game, being able to rank up your units, what's more fun than having an insanely elite group of units that can kill a dozen tanks or helicopters.

The campaign is also pretty amazing, considering, if this was published by someone else, they probably wouldn't have even made it.

NOTE: I may be considerably biased towards this game's review, since, I own all the series games, so... Yeah, But I've also only ever really ever known about the series since Wargame: Airland Battle which is also pretty amazing.

My final summery is, get the game if you can, if you can't, get the franchise especially since I decided to post this when I saw this, since, it's one of my favorite games! Oh! And another thing, they give out free map packs which, for both this and airland battle there is already like 4 free map packs out for each.

reviewText:
The best installment of the series IMHO.
Highly recommended for anyone who is interested in intricate RTS games and military technology!

An in-depth, somewhat realistic approach to modern warfare, with a relatively steep learning curve and a micro management intensive gameplay that will keep you pinned to the computer for hours. (Or scare you away, but do not be afraid! It is truly worth your patience).

I absolutely love it. Make a deck/army to use out of more than a thousand units, different infantry sections and vehicle variants and then carefully manage your Leopard tank to rock Soviet armour... or set up an ambush with infantry waiting for the enemy vehicles to pass, just to active RPGs, when they can fire a devastating sideshot into weak parts of enemy armour.... there are lots of such tactical possibilites, thanks to the well thought-out combat system.

This is not a rock-paper-scissor game like Starcraft. Just like in real life, every gun matters if properly used... no matter how elite your infantry is, it will get mowed down by the cheapest LMG on open ground, if you are not managing it properly and utilise cover and so aswell, the mightiest MBT can fall to auto cannon fire, should an IFV manage to sneak behind it.

Truly a very enjoyable mix of reality and gameplay-balance decisions. I am sure everyone can find his way to fight in this game, especially in gigantic battles with 20 players, where everyone counts.

Not to mention the absolutely stunning video engine, bringing great scaling and visuals, while retaining a good performance.

A great game for every wholehearted strategy fan.

11/10, I have proven my honor.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
If you are an rts player like myself, this game is new, challenging, and extremly entertaining.
Let me go a little bit more into detail.

Stuff you should know:
No base building (not that type of game)
Very strategic (requires real time decision making, plus longer strategic game plans)
Has a large skill curve (if you're starting off, play with bots or a friend)
Buuuuunch of units

This game is an amazing blend of tactical combat and strategic planning, with different units fufilling very different roles. All in all, this game will punish your mistakes, and reward your successes.

Before you buy
Watch a match of the wargame red dragon reddit tournament to see how the game is played, and judge for yourself if this is for you. I strongly recommend this game, as it has brought me countless hours of memorable fun.

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon is the final installment in Eugen System's Wargame series. It is an excellent, imperfect example of balancing realism with gameplay.

And it reminds me of the problem I have with my girlfriend.

I mean, she's a wonderful person. She's educated. More intelligent than I. Kind. Beautiful. But I dunno. It's just that I really really don't like defecating on her face.

In Wargame: Red Dragon, like in Wargame: Airland Battle, you can call in airplanes and have them drop their ordinance on enemies. The planes will fly in from off the map, and as long as they have fuel or haven't been shot down, they can produce beautiful explosions on their ground-based enemies.

But unlike the poo that falls on my girlfriend, there isn't anything discomforting about the bombs exploding on the virtual men. For you see, I don't even like the idea of pooping on people. Just thinking about it makes me feel....dirty somehow. I mean, I was raised in what I thought was a normal family, and we never said anything about pooing on people's faces.

Which brings me to the tanks in Red Dragon. Tanks have top, side, front, and rear armor. And just like in real life, the front armor is the strongest, and the armor on top is the weakest. So even if the heaviest enemy tanks get too close to infantry in buildings, they can be easily destroyed because their top armor is exposed to enemy AT.

Quite like my girlfriend's face. The thing is, she insists, no, DEMANDS that I relieve the contents of my large intestine onto her f. She says if I'm unwilling to do this, then we can't be together. And that as long as we share the same roof, I am to extirpate my feces onto her head weekly.

And as compelling as the gameplay is, with its potential to involve firefights in the mountains, dogfights in the skies, napalm engulfing forests, and 1000 kg bombs, the experience can feel somewhat stale after awhile. You get to the point where you feel like you've seen it all, and that there really isn't anything more worth learning. After all, not many people play the game. There are currently enough players to get into a match, but it's not like CS or DOTA 2 or LoL. You're unlikely to have anything resembling a balanced match in even three hours of playing (there's no match making system -- you just look for lobbies with open slots).

And the vast majority of us, I am sure, don't poop all over our lovers' faces. We just don't poo on people's faces in general. I mean, I guess some people do this as a sex act. Like, there's something called a dirty sanchez, which involves poo smear on a face. But that's not what my girlfriend's after. To her this isn't a sex act. It's romance. She says that pooing on her is the act of love, and that it is the only way (the only way) to keep our relationship alive.

Granted, you would think that with more than 1,200 units, plus the real-time nature of this beautiful, 3D strategy game, there would always be surprise and spontaneity in every match. But that's not true. Most battles involve players fielding an assortment of units designed to counter those of their opponents. And the assortments are predictable. I.e. there are a small handful of optimal assortments. Wildly different assortments will usually result in the defeat of the experimenter.

Experimentation is something we've definitely tried. But unloading fecal matter on my girlfriend's face is never interesting. It's just vile. I remember at first when she wanted to do this outside. I didn't want neighbors or school children to see me taking a dump on her, so I convinced her, after many hours, to have us do this in the bathtub.

Which brings us to the naval component of Red Dragon. It's a rather annoying affair, actually. It doesn't have the depth of the land battle, and if you lose the naval battle, you will almost certainly lose the entire battle. Almost the same can be said of the air battle, yes, but the air battle can take place pretty much anywhere on the map, while the naval part cannot. Also the air battle involves near-constant risk (the planes can be easily shot down), while the naval battle is (if both sides are compentent) undramatic and long. The ship combat does not compete with the sexy, vulnerable planes performing explosive runs.

And it's just disgusting having the runs while opening your sphincter and unleashing all that brown people soup on the woman you, just last night, took out to dinner; the contents of which are now all over her. I can't believe she needs this. It makes me fear that I will never understand her, and that her inability to understand my discomfort will cause her to never understand me. I worry that, if we were to marry, our philosophical differences regarding my poo on her face would ruin what's otherwise a beautiful relationship. Oh God!

So Red Dragon is a good game, but one you'll want to get with a good discount; right now it's too expensive, given that it's not much better than its predecessor. If you're new to the series, you'll want to get it with a friend who gets it when you do and is also a noob.

Sound: 7/10
Graphics: 9/10
Writing: 5/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Feminism: N/A
Jerkability: 6/10
Overall Score: 7/10 (WITH A SUFFICIENT DISCOUNT AND PLAYED WITH FRIENDS)

reviewText:
Wargame is back! This time though, You won't be shelling German towns or sneaking in Scandinavian forests, You'll be burning poor asian women and children with napalm one more time! Thats right, The Wargame Theatre of War is now Asia!

The game controls the same as EE and AirLand, but the folks at Eugen have added another layer of tactical micromanagement- Sea battles. The units never cease to amaze me how one second I can be applauding their perfect executions of my plans... To wondering how such braindead soldiers even understand the concept of breathing.

Nevertheless, The game still proves it is fun, challenging and intellegent even if it feels like AirLand battle with the prototype date pushed back to '95. The addition of the new counties is always welcome, and Japan, China, North and South Korea, and Australia fit perfectly in the numerous factions. The addition of coalitions and the reworking of deck types makes building and customizing decks an extremly fun pass time.

But newcomers to series be warned: THIS GAME HAS A LEARNING CURVE THAT RIVALS EVE. That's right, don't expect to drop in and beginning distributing letal doses of freedom, and the tutorials aren't worth jackshit. Still, If you got the balls and are willing to sick it out, the game is immensely fun and satisfying.

Experimentation is something we've definitely tried. But unloading fecal matter on my girlfriend's face is never interesting. It's just vile. I remember at first when she wanted to do this outside. I didn't want neighbors or school children to see me taking a dump on her, so I convinced her, after many hours, to have us do this in the bathtub.

Which brings us to the naval component of Red Dragon. It's a rather annoying affair, actually. It doesn't have the depth of the land battle, and if you lose the naval battle, you will almost certainly lose the entire battle. Almost the same can be said of the air battle, yes, but the air battle can take place pretty much anywhere on the map, while the naval part cannot. Also the air battle involves near-constant risk (the planes can be easily shot down), while the naval battle is (if both sides are compentent) undramatic and long. The ship combat does not compete with the sexy, vulnerable planes performing explosive runs.

And it's just disgusting having the runs while opening your sphincter and unleashing all that brown people soup on the woman you, just last night, took out to dinner; the contents of which are now all over her. I can't believe she needs this. It makes me fear that I will never understand her, and that her inability to understand my discomfort will cause her to never understand me. I worry that, if we were to marry, our philosophical differences regarding my poo on her face would ruin what's otherwise a beautiful relationship. Oh God!

So Red Dragon is a good game, but one you'll want to get with a good discount; right now it's too expensive, given that it's not much better than its predecessor. If you're new to the series, you'll want to get it with a friend who gets it when you do and is also a noob.

reviewText:
Wargame is back! This time though, You won't be shelling German towns or sneaking in Scandinavian forests, You'll be burning poor asian women and children with napalm one more time! Thats right, The Wargame Theatre of War is now Asia!

The game controls the same as EE and AirLand, but the folks at Eugen have added another layer of tactical micromanagement- Sea battles. The units never cease to amaze me how one second I can be applauding their perfect executions of my plans... To wondering how such braindead soldiers even understand the concept of breathing.

Nevertheless, The game still proves it is fun, challenging and intellegent even if it feels like AirLand battle with the prototype date pushed back to '95. The addition of the new counties is always welcome, and Japan, China, North and South Korea, and Australia fit perfectly in the numerous factions. The addition of coalitions and the reworking of deck types makes building and customizing decks an extremly fun pass time.

But newcomers to series be warned: THIS GAME HAS A LEARNING CURVE THAT RIVALS EVE. That's right, don't expect to drop in and beginning distributing letal doses of freedom, and the tutorials aren't worth jackshit. Still, If you got the balls and are willing to sick it out, the game is immensely fun and satisfying.

reviewText:
Excellent game here, which distinguishes itself from most RTS by forcing the player to apply actual military common sense to the battle rather than gamey common sense. No Action Per Minute contest or mathematically calculated rushes of a single unit to kill the other side. Learning the Art Of War in this game can be tough, but is also rewarding as hell, as outthinking the enemy will allow you to crush even the mightiest armored push.

The game is, in itself, really beautiful on the graphical side, and though the musics are not exceptional, they do their job correctly. The balancing might be disputed by some (usually the new players who think their favourite nation should crush everyone), but the fact is that BLUE and RED have the same amount of victories in multi, according to the released data.

If you want to see a game with more than a thousand different units, with each faction having its own character and way of waging war, if you want to play something that favours actual planning and competence rather than mechanical application of drilled builds and rushes, Red Dragon is for you.

Oh, and Eugen will release free DLC in the upcoming weeks and months. ;-)

reviewText:
It really pains me to change my review of this game but god damn did Red Dragon drop the ball on way too many things.

First off, the ships. They sucked from the get go, they were patched to suck less, and then were never touched on again. In other words, they still suck. A minor complaint to some as they are not mandatory, but considering it was basically the unique selling point of the game, its a shame that it never got the love or attention it really needed.

Secondly, the balance. Eugen doesn't know how or to whom its balancing its games. It seemed for a bit that there plan was to make a game that was balanced in such a way that the people who played it a lot and learned how to get real good at it, there game would be a very balanced affair. Meaning that people with not as much skill may not recognize counters or better strategies and tactics here or there, but they'd be there, they'd exist to be learned and taught.

But, if the idea of competitive Wargame ever became a huge thing to watch or experience I never heard of it, and so I think that whole idea fell through. Then there was this idea that they'd balance to realism. Which led to many fun arguments about why Hinds shouldn't have AA missiles and how the Marines didn't have LAVs as troop transports ever, both of which are hilariously false and dumb.

So now we get to the point where the balance has switched priorities and objectives, and has been screwed with and muddled up so many times that the other major selling point to wargame, the amount of units it has and the fun hardware that it has, its depth of units... is also false. There is a best deck for each nation. There really isn't that much tactical flexibility that would allow you to bring A instead of B, its just that this one deck will always win out all other things being equal.

All of which wouldn't be as bad if Eugen seemed to still be patching and fixing the game. But they're really not. They haven't touched it in quite a while, outside of adding in the new maps recently, and the community has kind of recognized that they've moved on to their other game Act of Aggression. Its a shame really because I think Red Dragon could have, with a half a years additional polish, made for a much better playing experience. But as it stands? Its a mess of different ideas and concepts and thoughts and mis-steps, that no one is even bothering to look at anymore.

reviewText:
Wargame: Red Dragon. Where to start? This is the thrid installment of the WarGame series. It is a semi-realistic game focusing on possitioning, strategy and tactics. It has over 1400 units from 17 nations to choose from. Every unit has limited ammo and fuel, maps are large. Recon and supplylines are crtical for victory.

The only bad things I can say about the game is that the naval aspect feels unfinished, it has no proper tutorial and some game mechanics seem rather obfuscated, the two latter things can be solved by reading guides made by the community as for ships they will hopefully feel more complete after tons of patching by the developer and free DLC. They do listen to the community and they do actively patch their games.

If you come into this game expecting something similar to Command & Conquer, StarCraft or Act of War don't. WarGame is a very different style of RTS.

There's no base building and you only get the units you choose to go to battle with. The way you choose your units is similar to a deck of cards. You build decks before going to battle. Each card holds a certain amount of units - the stronger and more modern the individual units are the less you get in each card for example you get over 30 T-34/85's in one card but you get only 1 M1A2 Abrams in a card, a deck consists of several cards under several categories: Logistics, Support, Infantry, Armour, Vehicle, Reconnaissance,Helicopter, Plane and Naval. If you choose only powerful units you may end up with no forces to fight with. Unit cards are also limited by type, amount and an overall limit on how many cards you can have. A deck should have a balance. In the campaigns you cannot make your own decks, they are predetermined.

You are not allowed to field your entire force at once. You are limited by points, you get these points by capturing zones with your command units - the more zones you hold the faster you accumulate those points - the more reinforcements you can call in.

The game has several game modes:
Destruction - Destroy enemy units for points, the more the enemy unit is worth the more points you get.
Conquest - hold more command zones than the enemy and reach a certain amount of conquest points to win.
Economy - similar to conquest, but you win by having a stronger economy than the enemy. You will be sending out units sparingly

You win by hitting the limit or by having more points than the enemy when time runs out or by destroying all the enemy command units.

This game has too many mechanics to descibe in a single steam review or maybe even a full review such as recon, camouflage, missile types, missile guidance types, tank shell types, and the list goes on. if they were all mentioned in detail we might end up with a book of sorts, even certain community guides for this game can be a 1000 word essay, but if you are open to learn them you fill find that WarGame: Red Dragon is a strategy game unlike all others and a very fun experience.

reviewText:
As someone who plays the SP side only, I'm actually enjoying WRD more than I'd expected.  Having entirely new armies (North Korea, South Korea, China, Japan, ANZAC) is fun.  I'd previously heard of the Type 59, the J7, the Korean K1, etc but never really understood what they were until having to lead or fight them in the campaigns.

The campaigns themselves are a pleasant surprise.  There are a few mechanics I miss from WALB, but overall, the new organization around companies & battalions leads to a much wider variety of tactical situations than WALB.  I've had some surprisingly interesting battles where I'm fighting with scraps of different formations and having to put together a novel tactical solution.

Far and away the best part of WRD is the variable speed.  While I eventually came to love WALB, the sheer franticness of the battles meant that I nearly always had to rely on setting up a defense and waiting for the AI to bash into me, since the AI could outmicro me in defending against my attacks (optimizing AH and ATGM ranges while simultaneously dropping mortars AND calling in CAS strikes :<).  With the new bullet time feature, I'm finally able to enjoy employing real tactics, and I can finally get down to ground level and enjoy the phenomenally beautiful engine.  There have been some amazing scenes that I always missed in WALB since I needed to stay high to monitor the entire board.

One downside is that the campaign map seems less well thought-out than WALB.  It's often unclear what you can and cannot do, and when you can't do an action (e.g. Assign a squadron to a new airbase), there's no explanation why.  I miss the cards" you could play in WALB around the actual movement of formations
hoursPlayed: naval strikes etc.  The ideal Wargame would blend the new mix-and-match formation system with the strategic actions and UI clarity from WALB.\n\nThe only other downside is that the AI seems to rely more on bull-rushing you with everything it has right at the start of every match.  My recollection is that WALB had a little more variety in how the AI would respond.  This may well be because they've removed some of the worst features of the "all-seeing" AI from WALB (thank you!)

reviewText:
[My review from metacritic with some changes]
This is 3rd game of the series. And have some Improvement over previous Wargames.

Best strategy game at the moment for sure. beats COH2 and MOW series easily In making sense and realism category.

But its not enough to give it 8 or 9. Especially when they wont learn from previous games.
Really huge and beautiful maps. Again planes and now Ships.  Aaah ships..you either hate them or love them..and the majority of the players hate them. Its cluster fOck of huge proprtion. And I played them in multi only once.
But you can have mixed maps with land units and naval..which is pretty cool to some point.

Rivers can be crossed now by swimming units - no choke points. Small naval units can swim there and so on.


You can really go crazy tactic now. It became much harder game since tank spams are not that successful any more.
I personally stopped using tanks at all.
Def. you have to be much more smarter and careful with your units.

Unfortunately instead of fixing basic issues they just keep adding more and more units.
Looks to me they spreading they attention on everything ships, planes and miillion units and nations.
Instead of narrowing and making it flawless.


After 2 games they finally added some features people were asking from beginning :
- map view in lobby,
- ban option from room ,

And it only took them 3 games to do it! Congrats Eugene! You are fast learners hehe.
Ask yourself a question why it took you soo long?

What kind of people work at Eugene that don't what's going on in multi games that you need to sometimes BAN people.
Once again, it took them 3 games to do it!

Stupidity of that team is pretty much visible. Yeah add more units to counter that.
But that would be it.
Still no black list, still no availability to see what kind of deck your team-mate have.

And other simple things that should be straight forward for strategy game. Looks like they hit their mind capacity and ideas limit. Good to know its last game from this series.

Still no strategy level in multi. It is in single player, but in multi ? nope.
Just one map game where everybody throws units on each other mindlessly without bigger picture option.
It seems nobody from strategy games devs can do it these days.
Wonder why is that? Would that mean people who make strategy games have no clue about those games and are not fans of them.. like Eugene.

Eugene studios had potential and some great ideas but it run out of them long time ago.
Since then their motto is ADD MORE UNITS".
Only because of the forum they were improving game. This is just sad.
Still you should buy this game despite my harsh review . Its only playable strategy game going towards realism atm. But don't expect miracles here.

And like always in Wargame series - good team-mates. Without them you are screwed.

I say like this On W:ALB I had 812 hours.

On W:RD I have only 100. So if you didnt played before in wargame series. BUY IT you will love it. If you did played before in wargame it wont have that initial sparkle to keep you long on it like me. But still is great game compared to others games in this genre .


Would I recommend this game? Despite those issues? YES."

reviewText:
This game combines the complexity and mechanics of card based or table top strategy games with the real time action of a conventional RTS.

That's a good thing if you understand that, but it means there is a steep learning curve to the game. You can not zerg in this game. Well you can, but you won't be very popular with your team mates.

Get to know the 100s of units' strengths and weaknesses, get to learn the complex mechanics, get to know the maps and their conventions and you there is a great sense of satisfaction to be had. You can't just jump in a guess though, and the game it's self doesn't offer anything in the way of education.

The interface is clunky, half the time a left click works half the time a right click works. The move button is labelled attack, the flank button is labelled move and the layout is keener to be 80's retro than usable and sane.

All that complexity and dedication to learn what's going on adds up to an unfriendly experience for new players. You play your first game and loose all your units in 20 seconds to rocket spam; then your team hates you for feeding the enemy. So in your second game you bring rocket spam and your team hates you for wasting their resource and attracting counter battery to supply routes and refuelling units. And so it goes on.

Playing as a team will be a much more rewarding experience. For a start  you have a chance to be competitive when facing servers stacked with other teams, and your co-ordination and collaboration will give you a huge advantage to counter-balance your nubness.

If you are a 'serious business' player and want a less simplistic RTS then this is right up your street, but it is in no sense a casual or accessible game, and games from outside the 'wargame' series will not have as much in common as you expect.
